column2: Diia.AI: The World's First National AI Agent for Government Services
column4: On September 1, 2025, Ukraine became the first country in the world to introduce an AI assistant for government services via its Diia portal. Announced by Digital Transformation Minister Mykhailo Fedorov on Telegram, the AI tool is currently in open beta testing. Designed to enhance convenience and efficiency, it guides users through accessing public services, recommends the most suitable options based on their personal situations, and can even provide vital personal data—such as insurance records—within the chat interface.

column2: Digital Management Platform for Public Administrations Sedipualb@
column4: SEDIPUALB@ is a digital platform created by the Provincial Council of Albacete to enable fully digital administrative management for municipalities. Initially launched to serve local governments within the province, it provides a shared, open, and interoperable system that simplifies administrative processes and eliminates barriers such as licensing costs or dependence on political cycles. Delivered as a Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution, the platform is built on open technologies and deployed in the cloud, ensuring scalability, flexibility, and cost-efficiency. Albacete became the only province in Spain where all municipalities adopted a unified digital management platform. Since then, SEDIPUALB@ has expanded well beyond its original scope. Today, more than 300 public entities—including municipalities, consortia, and universities across seven autonomous regions—use the system. It supports over a million citizens and thousands of concurrent users daily. Governance is collaborative, with technical, legal, and administrative bodies advising on improvements, while costs are distributed among participants according to usage. This model ensures both sustainability and transparency, turning a local project into a national benchmark for digital public administration.
column8: Provincial Council of Albacete (Diputación de Albacete)

column2: AI for Species Protection - Detection of Illegal Online Wildlife Trade
column4: Germany’s Federal Agency for Nature Conservation, together with the AI Lab at the German Environment Agency, developed an AI-driven tool to detect illegal online trading of protected species, one of the fastest-growing environmental crimes worldwide. The system combines AI-powered image classification, rule-based text analysis, and tailored web scraping to scan thousands of online listings daily, identifying species even when disguised or misspelled. During a six-month pilot, the tool flagged over 50,000 protected animals from more than 1,250 CITES-listed species, transforming an unmanageable manual task into a scalable, data-driven process. It frees public servants from repetitive screening, allowing them to focus on high-risk cases, improving efficiency, and strengthening enforcement. Built entirely in-house with open-source technologies, the system ensures digital sovereignty, sustainability, and compliance with European interoperability standards. It has already inspired international interest, including from the Czech CITES authority, and provides a transferable model for EU-wide biodiversity protection.
column8: AI Lab at the German Environment Agency (UBA)

column2: Impulsa Autónomo: Intelligent Platform to Personalise Grants and Subsidies for the Self-Employed in Galicia through AI
column4: The Xunta de Galicia developed an intelligent portal and widget to simplify access to grants and subsidies for self-employed professionals. By consolidating dispersed information into a single platform, the project reduces complexity and fragmentation in accessing funding opportunities. Using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)–based Generative AI, the system integrates official databases to provide personalised recommendations, outperforming static catalogues. It was designed for rapid deployment with iterative testing and direct user pilots, ensuring relevance and usability. Early results show search time reductions of more than 60% and over 100 hours of integrated specialised advisory services. BI dashboards track consultations, usage, and real-time satisfaction, while automated responses deliver cost savings for the administration. Transparency is reinforced through personalised publication of subsidies, automatic alerts, and two-way feedback channels that enhance citizen participation. Fully aligned with European interoperability principles and Spanish regulations, the platform strengthens government-to-citizen interaction, increases public participation, and provides a replicable model for digital public services.

column2: AI-Driven Market Surveillance to Safeguard Consumers in the Digital Single Market
column4: Launched in 2022 by the European Commission’s Directorate-General for Justice and Consumers (DG JUST), this project delivers an EU-wide platform that enables systematic surveillance of online marketplaces across all EU and EEA languages. By simulating human interaction to overcome obstacles like pop-ups, captchas, and hidden content, it ensures access to data that traditional crawlers cannot reach. The platform records dangerous products taken offline, fostering transparency, cross-border cooperation, and a shared view of enforcement progress. With the integration of large language models, the system significantly improves the precision of product identification, reducing false positives and enabling inspectors to focus on genuine risks. This shift accelerates enforcement cycles, supports Member States in handling the growing influx of imported parcels, and enhances consumer protection across the Single Market. Aligned with European interoperability principles and EU product-safety legislation, the platform connects seamlessly with the Safety Gate Rapid Alert System. It provides authorities with a cost-effective, centralised, and secure service that strengthens regulatory enforcement while generating valuable insights for future EU policy-making.

column2: The Responsive PIAO: An AI-Enabled Model for Proactive and Continuous Skill Development
column4: Launched by LepidaSCpA in collaboration with the Italian public administration, the project introduces a strategic, data-driven approach to staff training, aligning professional development directly with the organisational objectives set out in the Piano integrato di attività e organizzazione (PIAO). Using an iterative Plan-Do-Check-Act cycle, it optimises training investment by mapping identified needs to existing courses on national platforms, ensuring both efficiency and value for money. Generative AI models, employed under human supervision, supported the design and analysis of tools such as the “interests and perceived gaps questionnaire”, which improved communication between management and employees and fostered organisational trust. The pilot phase recorded high levels of user satisfaction, validating the methodology’s potential to shift training strategies from intuition to evidence-based planning. Fully aligned with the European Interoperability Framework, the project demonstrates legal, organisational, semantic, and technical interoperability. It enhances transparency by creating a structured channel for employee feedback and by making its standardised training course index publicly available, offering a replicable model for other administrations.

column2: GREEN-LOG Last-Mile Digital Control Tower: An AI-Driven Platform for Real-Time Optimisation and Sustainable Urban Logistics
column4: The GREEN-LOG Last-Mile Digital Control Tower (DCT), developed as part of the EU co-funded GREEN-LOG project, addresses the growing challenges of urban last-mile logistics driven by e-commerce expansion. The platform provides real-time monitoring of delivery assets, near real-time forecasting of transport demand and traffic conditions, and advanced data-driven analytics to enhance operational coordination among logistics service providers, city authorities, and other stakeholders. Leveraging AI-powered predictive models, dynamic multi-modal routing, and Logistics-as-a-Service (LaaS) Marketplace metrics, the system optimises fleet utilisation, reduces carbon emissions, and minimises urban congestion while improving delivery efficiency and reliability. Demonstrations across European cities, including Athens, Barcelona, and Flemish urban areas, have shown reductions in kilometres driven (-35%), travel time (-26%), and the number of stops (-12%), delivering both environmental and economic benefits. The DCT’s flexible, modular architecture enables deployment across diverse urban contexts, supports cross-modal routing, and integrates policy constraints and incentives set by local authorities. Its design aligns with the European Interoperability Framework, ensuring legal, semantic, organisational, and technical interoperability, GDPR compliance, and secure, transparent data sharing. Stakeholder engagement and continuous co-creation have driven usability and adoption, with user satisfaction reaching 90% in early 2026, demonstrating the platform’s effectiveness in supporting sustainable and efficient urban logistics.

column2: Decision Support System Supporting Intelligent Real-time Resource Allocation of Response Teams (RART) for wildfire suppression
column4: The RART tool, developed under the SILVANUS GreenDeal project by NETCOMPANY, is a Decision Support System designed to assist fire commanders in optimising wildfire response. By dynamically allocating available firefighting resources, including aerial and ground units, based on fire spread projections, population density, and resource availability, the system enhances situational awareness and enables more effective, timely interventions, reducing the impact on citizens, property, and the environment. The tool integrates open-source population data, AI-driven fire forecasting, and a multi-objective optimisation algorithm to guide resource deployment under complex, time-sensitive conditions. Field tests in October 2024 by the Region of Sterea Ellada, Greece, and simulations in France demonstrated high user satisfaction (>90%) and confirmed the system’s effectiveness in supporting decision-making under real-life constraints.
column8: Region of Central Greece (Perifereia Stereas Elladas), Greece

column2: AI-Driven Early Warning and Decision Support for Fraud Prevention in Quality-Labelled Food Supply Chains
column4: The ALLIANCE EWDSS, developed by Netcompany S.A. as part of the EU-funded ALLIANCE project, is an AI-powered system designed to detect and mitigate food fraud across complex supply chains. Focusing on sectors such as Feta Cheese, Organic Pasta, Organic Honey, and Fava Beans, the solution combines Artificial Intelligence, fuzzy logic, operations research, and multi-criteria decision analysis to provide early risk detection, transparent risk scoring, and actionable decision support for farmers, auditors, and regulators. The system employs domain-specific monitoring—including real-time pH and temperature data for feta cheese, anomaly detection for honey, and machine learning models for fava beans—to proactively identify potential fraud before it enters production. Developed through a co-creation approach, it ensures usability, transparency, and stakeholder engagement, enabling evidence-based decision-making, consistent risk management, and compliance with food safety and certification standards. By integrating human-in-the-loop decision support and standardised data models, ALLIANCE EWDSS fosters collaboration, accountability, and trust across the food supply chain, representing a significant advancement over conventional single-method detection systems.
column8: Bavarian State Office for Health and Food Safety (Bayerisches Landesamt für Gesundheit und Lebensmittelsicherheit – LGL)

column2: AI-Driven Harmonisation of Albanian Legislation with the EU Aquis
column4: The AI-assisted platform, developed by Microsoft in partnership with the Albanian Government, accelerates the transposition of EU legislation into Albanian law, enhancing both administrative efficiency (G2G) and public service quality (G2C, G2B). By combining AI-powered translation (ChatGPT-4 architecture) with automated compliance table generation, the system reduces manual effort, improves accuracy, and tracks thousands of EU measures and national acts requiring alignment. Implemented within the existing PIEA (European Integration and Membership Platform), the solution supports Albanian institutions without restructuring, providing real-time access to CELEX documents and ensuring full interoperability across legal, organisational, semantic, and technical levels. Phase 2 introduces AI-based legal analysis to detect overlaps and contradictions, helping Albania stay on track to meet its EU integration objectives by 2030.
column8: National Agency of Information Society, under the Prime Minister’s authority
column11: Executive and legislative organs, financial and fiscal affairs, external affairs.

column2: Archimede (Antifrode) - Evolution of Anti-Fraud Systems and Continuous Internal Auditing
column4: Archimede is an AI-driven solution developed by INAIL to detect and anticipate errors, evasions, and fraud (EEF), supporting effective risk prevention policies and highlighting process anomalies. During testing, the system demonstrated high accuracy: in six central audits, 100% of flagged cases were confirmed as anomalous, with 44% showing non-compliance in case handling. By integrating with INAIL’s auditing systems and the CRIBIS business information database, Archimede enables the identification of mismanagement and process irregularities, forming a core component of ongoing monitoring and auditing strategies. Built as a versatile, open-source on-premise solution, it ensures secure handling of confidential data and is fully adapted to INAIL’s organisational and analytical context, providing a competitive technological advantage.
column8: Italian National Institute for Insurance against Accidents at Work (INAIL)

column2: The Pre-University Management Information System (SMIP/PUMIS)
column4: The Smart Management Information Platform (SMIP) was introduced to modernise Albania’s education governance and overcome the inefficiencies of manual, paper-based processes, fragmented communication, and limited digital access. As a unified platform, SMIP brings together education, health, and administration in a way not previously available in the country. It currently integrates more than 407,000 students, 35,000 teachers, and 800,000 parents, providing real-time academic updates for families, digital reporting tools for teachers, and centralised dashboards for education authorities. The platform also supports wider public services, such as issuing over 10,000 digital vaccine cards via the national e-Albania portal, and promoting digital literacy, with more than 74,000 students trained in ICT skills through SmartLabs. By interoperating with national systems like e-Albania, the e-Vaccine system, and the NAIS Government Data Centre, SMIP improves efficiency, reduces bureaucracy, and strengthens transparency in education management. Aligned with the country’s Digital Agenda 2022–2026 and designed in line with EIF interoperability principles, SMIP enables evidence-based policy-making, enhances parental engagement, and lays the foundation for future regional cooperation, including cross-border diploma recognition.
column8: National Agency for Information Society (NAIS) – in cooperation with the Ministry of Education and Sports.

column2: Cruscotto infortuni - Cognitive Systems for Road Accidents
column4: The Road Accident Analysis Dashboard, developed by INAIL, strengthens workplace safety policies by providing structured data and AI-driven insights into incidents that significantly contribute to annual injury statistics. Designed for the Central Health Supervisory Authority, the tool enables the identification of trends, risk factors, and intervention areas, supporting more targeted prevention strategies. Based on Oracle Analytics Server, Cloudera, and IBM Watson, the platform integrates institutional records with predictive analytics to improve data accuracy and uncover previously unclassified accidents. It currently covers incidents from 2018 onwards and will expand to a ten-year overview, with updates every six months. Early adoption shows strong user engagement, high satisfaction, and recognised added value, making it a reliable foundation for evidence-based decision-making and future predictive planning.
column8: Italian National Institute for Insurance against Accidents at Work (INAIL)

column2: MyInail Chatbot - support tool for INAIL users
column4: The MyInail Chatbot provides users with guided, conversational support across INAIL’s wide range of services, from healthcare and financial benefits to prevention and training. Launched in June 2024, it improves accessibility to INAIL’s knowledge base while directing users to the most appropriate support channels when needed. Integrated into both the INAIL web portal and mobile app, the chatbot reduces contact centre calls, ensures secure and privacy-compliant interactions, and is continuously updated through user feedback. Early adoption shows strong satisfaction and no reported service complaints, confirming its role as a reliable first-level assistance and knowledge management tool.
column8: Italian National Institute for Insurance against Accidents at Work (INAIL)

column2: AI-powered Linguistic Mediator: A Phygital Solution for Inclusive and Accessible Public Services at INAIL
column4: To respond to the needs of an increasingly diverse workforce—20% of insured workers in Italy are foreign-born—INAIL has developed the Linguistic Mediator, an AI-powered tool that provides real-time voice and text interpretation at service counters. Integrated into INAIL’s “phygital” service model, it helps front-office staff, social workers, and doctors communicate effectively with non-Italian-speaking users, improving access to services while streamlining internal processes. Early pilots in territorial offices have shown strong results, with translation accuracy around 92% and clear efficiency gains for staff. Built on Microsoft Azure AI Services, the solution is modular, secure, and interoperable, with future extensions planned for document translation and Italian Sign Language (LIS).
column8: Italian National Institute for Insurance against Accidents at Work (INAIL)

column2: JuntaGPT: the internal GenAI based assistant for civil servants within the biggest regional administration in Europe.
column4: In June 2025, the Andalusian Regional Government launched JuntaGPT, an on-premises generative AI assistant for its internal personnel — over 240,000 civil servants — to help with document drafting, normative queries, summarising, email writing, and other administrative text work. Developed by the regional digital agency (ADA) and deployed on the Hércules supercomputer at CICA, the system is designed to ensure digital sovereignty, data protection, and that all information remains securely within the Junta’s environment. It allows users to upload documents, ask questions naturally, chain conversational queries, and access pre-loaded information by domain without always having to upload files. Early stages of deployment are underway; the tool is already partly active and intended to improve productivity, efficiency, and internal service quality by streamlining the drafting and information-retrieval tasks of public employees.

column2: On Record, a tool to help engage youth and other stakeholders in current decision-making processes.
column4: Portugal launched the “On Record” platform to address the democratic challenge of politically disengaged youth, despite their digital savviness. Developed by LabX/ARTE with support from the Portuguese Institute for Sport and Youth (IPDJ) and the Cascais Municipality, the project is part of the EU-funded initiative Improving Civic Participation through Emerging Technologies. On Record is a modular, AI-enabled deliberation and engagement platform embedded in Participa.gov, designed specifically to amplify youth voices (ages 14–30) in policymaking. It combines structured dialogue environments, gamified learning tools, AI-powered transcription and summarisation, and user tracking to ensure continuity across participation cycles. Pilots (2025) have shown its capacity to lower barriers to participation, foster inclusive debate, and enhance transparency by linking proposals to policy follow-up. With interoperability built into its architecture, GDPR compliance, and integration with national digital identity tools, the solution is both scalable within Portugal and transferable across Europe. By co-designing with youth and institutions, Portugal is creating a sustainable digital public good that strengthens trust, accountability, and democratic engagement, while setting the foundations for broader adoption beyond youth participation.
column8: Agency for State Technological Reform Agency (ARTE), Portuguese Institute for Sport and Youth (IPDJ) and the Cascais Municipality

column2: KIEZ - an Agentic AI Assistant for Development Cooperation
column4: KIEZ is an AI-powered assistant developed by the Datalab of the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) to support public servants in processing large volumes of text and improving decision-making in the domain of economic cooperation. Built as a trustworthy chat interface, KIEZ integrates agentic tools, domain-specific prompt templates, document uploads, controlled internet search, and internal databases, while balancing usability with strict privacy, security, and vendor-independence measures. The platform enables tasks such as document summarisation, translation, and refinement, and operates on a cloud-native, GDPR-compliant infrastructure that supports multiple AI models, including retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). KIEZ has already demonstrated strong impact, with 44% of surveyed staff rating it “important” or “very important” to their work and 51% reporting improvements in efficiency and communication. With over 1.6 million tokens processed daily, KIEZ exemplifies a scalable, secure, and interoperable AI solution for modernising public administration workflows, funded by NextGenerationEU.
column8: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)

column2: Alhambra and Generalife Digital Twin Living Lab: Technology to Preserve Beauty.
column4: The Alhambra Living Lab is an initiative led by the Andalusian Digital Agency (ADA) to develop a comprehensive digital twin of the Alhambra and Generalife palaces in Granada. Announced by Antonio Sanz, Regional Minister for the Presidency, Interior, Social Dialogue, and Administrative Simplification, and supported by Patricia del Pozo, Regional Minister for Culture and Sport, and Marifrán Carazo, Mayor of Granada, the project seeks to transform how visitors experience the Nasrid complex while improving its conservation, accessibility, and sustainability. Funded with over €3.2 million (€3,226,546) through the Spain Living Lab initiative within the Territorial Networks of Technological Specialisation (RETECH) programme, the Alhambra Living Lab will run until June 2026. The project integrates advanced technologies, including 3D modeling, IoT sensors, AI, mixed reality, and blockchain, to create a virtual replica of the monuments. This digital twin will allow the testing of innovative solutions to manage visitor flows, monitor environmental and structural conditions, enhance cultural engagement, and support sustainable heritage preservation. The first use cases are expected to launch in the first quarter of 2025, providing actionable insights for both site management and visitors. By combining state-of-the-art digital technologies with real-world heritage conservation, the Alhambra Living Lab represents one of Europe’s most forward-thinking cultural digital twin projects, offering a model for balancing tourism, sustainability, and citizen engagement.

column2: ParticipApp - more inclusive, transparent, and effective citizen participation in government decision-making
column4: ParticipApp is a national digital platform designed to make citizen participation in government decision-making more inclusive, transparent, and effective. The platform allows contributions in all co-official languages of Spain, and supports multiple input types, including text, voice, and images of handwritten notes. Using AI-powered tools, ParticipApp clusters and summarizes contributions thematically, helping participants and policymakers make sense of large volumes of input. The platform also provides AI-assisted drafting, enabling users to refine proposals while retaining full control over their content. Highly supported ideas can then be routed to a voting phase and formally considered in policy processes. For administrators, ParticipApp offers comprehensive dashboards to monitor participation, track emerging trends, moderate contributions, and measure engagement and impact. Built on open-source frameworks like Decidim and Consul and hosted on GDPR-compliant EU infrastructure, the platform is modular, scalable, and interoperable with existing digital public services. ParticipApp lowers barriers to participation, particularly for marginalised groups or those with limited digital literacy, and ensures transparency by providing visible summaries of contributions and clear feedback on how ideas are integrated into decision-making. By combining AI with human oversight, the platform strengthens public trust, enhances the quality and legitimacy of consultations, and establishes a sustainable digital public infrastructure for participatory governance, with potential for adoption across other European countries.

column2: Integration of an Innovative Product – AI Technology – into Public Procurement Object Price Analysis and Forecasting, and Centralized Public Procurement Savings Identification Procedures
column4: The Republic of Lithuania is pioneering the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into centralised public procurement to improve efficiency, transparency, and cost-effectiveness. Led by CPO LT, the national Central Purchasing Body, this project uses a generative AI solution — including large language models (LLMs) and advanced analytics — to analyse procurement prices, forecast costs, and calculate actual savings. In 2024, CPO LT managed €1.245 billion in procurements, representing around 15% of Lithuania’s total public procurement.The AI tool enables real-time market price analysis, identifies overpriced offers, predicts procurement values with high accuracy, and optimises supplier selection. These capabilities result in lower prices, reduced resource requirements for contracting authorities, increased supplier competition, and greater trust in procurement processes. The project complies with EU interoperability and procurement regulations, aligns with the European AI Act, and integrates open data sources such as CPO LT’s catalogue and kainos24.lt. Developed by NFQ Technologies, it is the first AI-based public procurement solution in Lithuania and represents a scalable model for other EU Member States. The pilot version is currently undergoing testing, with full deployment expected in December 2025, marking a significant step towards more transparent and efficient public procurement in the country.

column2: Once-Only Common Services: Portugal uses cloud native, cloud agnostic building blocks to make accessing the Single Market simple and easier for EU citizens and businesses
column4: Portugal is making it easier for citizens to live, study, work, or retire in other EU countries through the Once-Only Technical System (OOTS), an EU-wide framework that reduces the administrative burden of cross-border procedures. With OOTS, citizens and businesses only need to submit required documents (“evidences”) once, as these can be securely exchanged between public authorities across Member States, including permits, certificates, diplomas, or licenses. In December 2023, Portugal went live with the OOTS Common Services, which enable interoperability between procedure portals across the EU, covering around 80,000 national competent authorities. The system reuses existing technical components like eID and eDelivery, and is developed as open-source, ensuring scalable, secure, and GDPR-compliant operations. OOTS simplifies life events such as registering a vehicle abroad, studying, or running a business, while improving administrative efficiency, trust in shared data, and transparency. Early studies suggest that SMEs and self-employed workers could save up to 50% of costs and time when completing cross-border procedures. Students applying to study abroad can also save days or weeks in administrative processes. Portugal is now progressing to level 5 on the OOTS Acceleratormeter, aiming for the first live transactions in collaboration with the Directorate-General for Higher Education. Through OOTS, Portugal contributes to a seamless EU digital single market, enabling faster, more transparent, and citizen-centric public services across Europe.

column2: (AILUME) - Artificial Intelligence-Based Application for the Early Detection of Forest Fire Outbreaks
column4: AILUME is an artificial intelligence system developed to strengthen Galicia’s response to one of its greatest environmental threats: forest fires. The region’s vast forest coverage, rural depopulation, and increasing climate change impacts make early detection essential. AILUME addresses this by continuously analysing video streams from the Xunta de Galicia’s forest surveillance camera network, strategically placed across the territory. Using advanced deep learning models, optimised YOLO detectors, and vision-language reasoning, the system identifies smoke, filters false alarms, and provides explainable alerts to operators at the Central Coordination Center for Forest Fire Defense. The platform combines state-of-the-art AI with robust software architecture: a Django-based modular backend, Apache Kafka for distributed real-time processing, PyAV/OpenCV for video capture, and PostgreSQL for structured data management. It includes a human-in-the-loop feedback system, ensuring that operator validation contributes to continuous learning and higher detection accuracy. Designed for resilience and scalability, the solution can handle dozens of concurrent video streams with sub-second data latency, operating 24/7 under real production conditions. Pilot testing launched in August 2025 has confirmed its effectiveness: 86.1% detection success in real-world cases, precision of 98.2%, recall of 99.9%, and detection lead times averaging 18 minutes earlier than official notification channels. The system has already proven especially valuable in depopulated rural areas where traditional surveillance is limited, outperforming commercial alternatives in both accuracy and speed.
